SI Units.Name: Meter
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of length
SI Units.Description: A meter is the base unit of length in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the distance light travels in a vacuum in 1/299,792,458 of a second.

SI Units.Name: Kilogram
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of mass
SI Units.Description: The kilogram is the base unit of mass in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the mass of a platinum-iridium cylinder stored by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures.

SI Units.Name: Second
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of time
SI Units.Description: The second is the base unit of time in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the cesium-133 atom.

SI Units.Name: Ampere
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of electric current
SI Units.Description: The ampere is the base unit of electric current in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the flow of one coulomb of electric charge per second.

SI Units.Name: Kelvin
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of thermodynamic temperature
SI Units.Description: The kelvin is the base unit of thermodynamic temperature in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the fraction 1/273.16 of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water.

SI Units.Name: Candela
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of luminous intensity
SI Units.Description: The candela is the base unit of luminous intensity in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the luminous intensity in a given direction of a source that emits monochromatic radiation of frequency 540 × 1012 hertz and that has a radiant intensity in that direction of 1/683 watt per steradian.

SI Units.Name: Mole
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of amount of substance
SI Units.Description: The mole is the base unit of amount of substance in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the amount of substance of a system which contains as many elementary entities as there are atoms in 0.012 kilogram of carbon-12.

SI Units.Name: Hertz
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of frequency
SI Units.Description: The hertz is the base unit of frequency in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to one cycle per second.

SI Units.Name: Newton
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of force
SI Units.Description: The newton is the base unit of force in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the force that gives a mass of one kilogram an acceleration of one metre per second squared.

SI Units.Name: Pascal
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of pressure
SI Units.Description: The pascal is the base unit of pressure in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to one newton per square metre.

SI Units.Name: Volt
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of electric potential
SI Units.Description: The volt is the base unit of electric potential in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the difference of electric potential between two points of a conducting wire carrying a constant current of one ampere when the power dissipated between these points is one watt.

SI Units.Name: Joule
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of energy
SI Units.Description: The joule is the base unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the energy transferred to an object by the work of moving it a distance of one metre against a force of one newton.

SI Units.Name: Watt
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of power
SI Units.Description: The watt is the base unit of power in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to one joule per second.

SI Units.Name: Coulomb
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of electric charge
SI Units.Description: The coulomb is the base unit of electric charge in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the charge carried by one ampere per second.

SI Units.Name: Tesla
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of magnetic flux density
SI Units.Description: The tesla is the base unit of magnetic flux density in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to one weber per square metre.

SI Units.Name: Henry
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of inductance
SI Units.Description: The henry is the base unit of inductance in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the inductance of a closed circuit in which an electromotive force of one volt is produced when the electric current in the circuit varies uniformly at a rate of one ampere per second.

SI Units.Name: Siemens
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of electrical conductance
SI Units.Description: The siemens is the base unit of electrical conductance in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the reciprocal of the ohm.

SI Units.Name: Weber
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of magnetic flux
SI Units.Description: The weber is the base unit of magnetic flux in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the flux which, linking a circuit of one turn, would produce in it an electromotive force of one volt if it were reduced to zero at a uniform rate in one second.

SI Units.Name: Ohm
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of electrical resistance
SI Units.Description: The ohm is the base unit of electrical resistance in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the resistance between two points of a conductor when a constant potential difference of one volt, applied to these points, produces in the conductor a current of one ampere, the conductor not being the seat of any electromotive force.

SI Units.Name: Sievert
SI Units.Abbreviation: Metric system/SI unit of radiation dose
SI Units.Description: The sievert is the base unit of radiation dose in the International System of Units (SI). It is equal to the dose of radiation that will cause a change of one joule of energy per kilogram of matter.
